sentences.text: So hello everyone, I am Vik Shant, so today we will be learning about OOPS, Object-Oriended Programming.

improvement.reason: Typo in 'Object-Oriended Programming' and missing a brief definition of OOP's purpose.
improvement.suggestion: So hello everyone, I am Vik Shant, and today we will be learning about OOPS, which stands for Object-Oriented Programming, a paradigm focused on organizing code around objects rather than functions.

sentences.text: We will take a real simple example of a coffee machine and we will see. So think of the coffee machine as a class, it is like a blueprint, it defines the functions of a coffee machine like making a coffee, making a cappuccino, a latte, etc.
Now, when you buy a real coffee machine, it is like an object, right?
It is by it and placed on a table, like an object. Now let us come to the OOPS part of it.

improvement.reason: Unclear phrasing 'It is by it' and abrupt transition. Should clarify moving to OOP's core principles.
improvement.suggestion: You buy it and place it on a table, like a tangible object. Now, let's delve into the core principles, or pillars, of Object-Oriented Programming.

sentences.text: The OOPS has four different pillars, the first one is encapsulation.
Now, what is the capsule, it is the capsule, right? What is the capsule, it has some medicine inside and it is hidden by the outer capsule.

improvement.reason: Redundant phrasing 'what is the capsule, it is the capsule' and could be more direct about the concept of bundling.
improvement.suggestion: Think of a physical capsule: it contains medicine inside, which is hidden and protected by the outer casing.

sentences.text: Now in terms of the coffee machine, a coffee machine has some internal wiring, it has a heating element, it has a coffee grinder, it is all hidden under the outer casing.
Now this is encapsulation like bundling of data and hiding under a casing.

improvement.reason: 'Bundling of data' is vague; should specify data and methods/behaviors in a programming context.
improvement.suggestion: In programming, encapsulation is like bundling related data (attributes) and the methods (functions) that operate on that data into a single unit, while hiding the internal implementation details.

sentences.text: Now moving on to the next one, it is abstraction. Now it may seem like a big term but really isn't.
Now suppose I want to express it. Now how do you say to the machine like I just press a button off, I press one and it gives me an express.

improvement.reason: Likely transcription errors ('express it', 'button off') and awkward sentence structure.
improvement.suggestion: Now, suppose I want an espresso. How do I interact with the machine? I simply press a button, and it gives me an espresso.

sentences.text: I don't care about the steps to make an express right, that is handled by the machine.

improvement.suggestion: I don't care about the complex internal steps required to make an espresso; that intricate process is handled by the machine itself.

sentences.text: So it is, the machine is abstracting the function to make an express and simply giving me a button.

improvement.reason: Likely transcription error ('express') and clunky phrasing.
improvement.suggestion: The machine is abstracting away the complex function of making an espresso and simply providing me with a straightforward button to achieve the desired result.

sentences.text: That is abstraction. Moving on to the next one, it is inheritance.
Now inheritance is really simple, it is like you inherit your father's property, right?
Now in terms of the coffee machine, like suppose you have a smaller coffee machine and then your budget increases and you buy a premium one.
Now suppose the smaller one only makes espresso and heats up water.
And the premium one, it makes tapuccino, it makes elate and it also makes, it definitely makes an espresso and heats up water, right?

improvement.reason: Likely transcription errors ('tapuccino', 'elate') and repetitive phrasing.
improvement.suggestion: And the premium one makes cappuccino, latte, and it also definitely makes an espresso and heats up water, building on the basic functionalities.

sentences.text: So it is inheriting the properties of the base one and also addigates own properties.

improvement.suggestion: So, the premium machine is inheriting all the properties and functionalities of the base model, and then adding its own unique properties and features.

sentences.text: Now think in terms of cars, you have a base version and then you have a higher end model.
Now obviously the higher end model has all the features of the base one plus some extra features, right?
Now moving on to the last one with this fallen morphism.

improvement.suggestion: Now, moving on to the last pillar, which is polymorphism.

sentences.text: Now it seems like a complex term, but it is really simple, what it simply means is many forms or multiple forms.
Now suppose I have two coffee machines, one of brand X and one of brand Y.
Now I have a same button, brew on both of them. Now when I press the brew button on the brand X, it makes an espresso.
When I press the same button on brand Y, it makes a filter coffee.
Now the same function, the same button, performs multiple function, it appears in multiple forms.

improvement.reason: Grammatical error ('multiple function' instead of 'multiple functions').
improvement.suggestion: Here, the same function, triggered by the same button, performs multiple different actions or appears in multiple forms depending on the object it's called on.

sentences.text: That is polymorphism. That's right time guys, I have my vaccine everything well.

improvement.reason: The latter part of the sentence is completely off-topic and irrelevant to the lecture content.

sentences.text: Thank you so much.
